preparation_steps: Test soil pH to 6.0-7.0 using digital meter 2-3 weeks before planting
Work 2-3 inches compost into top 8 inches soil when temperature reaches 50°F
Choose location with full sun to partial shade receiving 6-8 hours direct sunlight daily
planting_steps: Start purple kale seeds indoors 6-8 weeks before 2025-05-10 at 70-75°F soil temperature
Sow seeds 0.25 inches deep with 12 inch spacing between plants
Transplant outdoors 2 weeks after 2025-05-10 when nighttime temperatures stay above 50°F
care_instructions: Water purple kale deeply 1-1.5 inches per week checking soil moisture 2 inches deep every 3 days
Apply 10-10-10 fertilizer at 2 tablespoons per plant every 3 weeks starting 2 weeks after transplant
Mulch with 2-3 inches organic matter keeping 6 inches away from plant stem
pest_management: Inspect purple kale weekly for common zone 4a-6a pests from May through September
Apply neem oil spray at 2 tablespoons per gallon water every 14 days if pests detected
Use floating row covers first 3 weeks after transplant to prevent early season pest damage
harvest_instructions: Begin harvesting purple kale approximately 50 days after transplant when fruits reach full size
Harvest in early morning 6-8 AM when temperatures below 75°F for best quality and flavor
Cut stems with clean sharp shears 1/4 inch above leaf node to encourage continued production
storage_tips: Store fresh purple kale at 55-60°F with 85% humidity for maximum 7-10 days after harvest
Blanch and freeze within 24 hours of harvest - maintains quality for 8-12 months in freezer
Preserve excess using canning or dehydrating methods appropriate for vegetable type

plant_groupings.spacing_notes: Plant purple kale and tomato in alternating rows, with 12 inches between each plant. This will allow for good air circulation and prevent disease.

general_tips: Start seedlings indoors 4-6 weeks before the last frost date to give them a head start on the growing season.
Choose varieties of tomato and kale that are specifically bred for cooler climates and shorter growing seasons, such as 'Brandywine' or 'Red Russian'.
In Moncton's cold climate, it's essential to provide protection from extreme temperatures. Use row covers or cold frames to extend the growing season.
Purple kale is a cool-season crop and prefers the cooler temperatures of spring or fall. Plant in early spring as soon as the soil can be worked, or in late summer for a fall harvest.

Tomatoes need full sun (at least 6 hours of direct sunlight) and well-draining soil to thrive. Make sure your garden bed has good drainage and consider adding organic matter like compost to improve soil fertility.

In Moncton's short growing season, it's crucial to make the most of every day. Use a trellis or cage to support indeterminate tomato plants and keep them upright, promoting healthy growth and fruiting.
Keep an eye out for pests like aphids, slugs, and snails that can damage your crops in Moncton's humid climate. Use organic pest control methods whenever possible.
